_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Support Activities for Road Transportation
Other Support Activities for Road Transportation

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Dow Corning Corp. (www.dowcorning.com) is a member of the American Chemistry Council. As such, the company uses the Responsible Care(R) management system to voluntarily improve its environmental, health, and safety performance.



Dow Corning's Carrollton, Ky. manufacturing facility (www.dowcorning.com/carrollton) has implemented a Risk Management Plan. The company has established a Code of Business Conduct to guide its employees. The facility maintains communication with the community through its Community Advisory Panel and other activities.



Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies



Dow Corning uses policies and procedures to manage environmental, health, safety and security performance. In addition, the facility has implemented safety and environmental management systems.



Facility overview and regulated substances



The facility manufactures chlorosilanes, methyl chloride, and silicone products. The facility uses the following regulated substances: anhydrous hydrogen chloride, aqueous hydrochloric acid, dimethyldichlorosilane, methyl chloride, methyltrichlorosilane, tetramethylsilane, trichlorosilane, and trimethylchlorosilane. 



Accident prevention program



The facility uses a systematic approach to prevent accidental releases, which includes policies, procedures, training, preventive maintenance, safety reviews, change management, investigations, and audits. The facility is a Star site in the Ky. Dept. of Labor's Voluntary Protection Partnership (VPP) and has conducted security and vulnerability assessments through its association with the American Chemistry Council, Federal Bureau of Investigation, local law enforcement agencies, and the Coast Guard.



In addition, the facility has implemented chemical-specific accident prevention measures, including:



- Use of nitrogen to inert vessels and storage tanks

- Use of high-performance, corrosion- and wear-resistant materials

- Methyl chloride continuous ai

r monitoring

- Automated emergency shutdown systems

- Emergency cooling on methyl chloride reactors

- Emergency hydrogen chloride scrubbers



Five-year accident history



The facility had two accidents (per 68.42) in the previous five years. In 2010 a methyl chloride compressor experienced a bearing failure causing a short duration leak and subsequent fire which resulted in minor property damage. One emergency responder showed symptoms of methyl chloride exposure, was examined by medical personnel and returned to work with no restrictions. A subsequent release of methyl chloride occurred on 27th October 2013 due to accidently venting through a maintenance line on start up of a compressor. No injuries or exposure to personnel occurred.



Emergency response program



The facility uses the Incident Command System for emergency planning and response activities. The facility coordinates its emergency response plan with the Carroll Co., Ky. Local Emergency Planning Committee and can respond to any foreseeable emergency. The facility also conducts periodic drills, trains emergency response personnel, and participates in community-wide drills.



Planned changes to improve safety



The Dow Corning Carrollton, Ky. facility strives to continuously improve its environmental, health, safety and security performance through management system and equipment reliability improvements. The facility uses a project-oriented approach to improve performance.



2012 Covered Process Changes



-One idle process has been decommissioned and removed from the list of covered processes.

-Two existing processes were added due to planned inventory increases.

-One covered process was created from portions of two existing processes to better align the different manufacturing activities (NAICS codes) and management systems.  No site process activities were added or deleted in creating this additional process.



PHA Date Error Discovered



During the Resubmission data collection a PHA da

te error was discovered and the RMP*eSubmit software will not allow the date to be corrected to an earlier date.  The EPA RMP*eSubmit technical support personnel (Lourdes at 703-227-7650 on 5/10/12) supported our suggestion to put an explanation of the error in the Executive Summary.  The "7.4.a Date of last PHA or PHA update" for Process Name 1000034078 CTN12 is incorrectly entered as 02/01/2011 and should be 10/02/2009.  The corresponding "7.4.c Expected or actual date of completion of all changes resulting from the last PHA or PHA update" for the same process is currently blank and should be 12/23/2009.
